awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Obligation and Relationality in the Wake of Critical Events
awd_abstract_narration:
Critical events can catalyze new forms of social relations or anchor new modes of collective life. Critical events (major occurrences, such as natural disasters, conflict, or economic crises that redefine social categories) have typically been explored in the aftermath of isolated incidents. This doctoral dissertation project investigates how people’s sense of obligation to others comes to be defined, experienced, and materialized in the context of multiple critical events that accrue over time. Existing research on obligation focuses on reciprocity and exchange and tends to paint a linear account of how solicitations of obligations form and bind people to one another. This dissertation research will instead attend to the tangled processes through which people’s sense of obligation to others is brought into relief and called into question in the wake of layered critical events. In addition to supporting the training of a doctoral student, the findings from this project will be shared with academic audiences as well as humanitarian and cultural non-governmental organizations.

The project traces different modes of response, including assistance and documentation, that people draw on to respond to layers of critical events. This multi-sited ethnography will encompass members of different generations and residents of different locales, and will deploy a combination of semi-structured interviews, participant observation, and oral life history interviews to explore the factors that guide people’s responses to events, how sociality and community boundaries become (re)configured as a result of these responses, and how meanings of critical events change as they accrue over time. In doing so, this broadens the spatial and temporal scope of the anthropological study of obligation and contributes to social science by better understanding the processes and forces through which boundaries of community are made and remade.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This dissertation research was supported by an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant under the project title, "Obligation and Relationality in the Wake of Critical Events." The project investiages how people’s experiences of and responses to critical events impact their sense of obligation to others. 

This research consisted of twelve months of ethnographic research, which included participant observation and semi-structured interviews, in Beirut, Lebanon. I studied two response programs that occured following the 2020 Beirut port explosion. The goal of this research was to understand the various social and economic factors that impacted how, when and to whom people connected to Lebanon felt obligated towards and responded to following the 2020 Beirut port blast in a context with a rich history of critical events. The first response program I studied was an assistance program implemented by a community kitchen NGO that was established around the time of the 2020 Beirut port explosion and continues to deliver 600 daily hot meals exclusively to Lebanese citizens residing in three neighborhoods in Beirut. The second was a documentation project by a Beirut-based independent platform for accountability journalism that reports on Lebanon’s sociopolitical crises. In the aftermath of the 2020 Beirut port explosion the journalists took it upon themselves to record the names of the non-Lebanese citizens (refugees and migrant workres) who were intentionally left off of the official state list of those killed in the blast. By analyzing these particular assistance and documentation responses alongside one another, this research investigated factors that influence whom people feel obligated towards, how people put this feeling into practice, and the different boundaries of communities that occur through these responses. 

Intellectual Merit: My research contributes to what I term the “anthropology of obligation” by investigating the processes through which obligation is brought into relief and called into question. Anthropology’s conventional focus on reciprocity, exchange, and a single event tends to paint a linear account of how obligations form and bind people to one another. My research assesses how experiences, memories, and responses to layers of critical events impact (or not) who is deemed “near” or “far” and how the borders of “us” and “them” change. In doing so, I broaden the scope of the anthropological inquiry into obligation by drawing on memories of previous events and experiences of current events to rethink the processes and forces through which obligation and community boundaries form.

Broader Impact: This research will culminate in my PhD dissertation which will be completed by 2026. Findings will be disseminated through several academic and popular forums (conferences, workshops, seminars) and outputs (journal articles, blog posts, podcasts), and with academics, my research interlocutors, and the general public. The results from this researh can be used by anthropologists, sociologists, social workers, Middle East scholars, memory studies scholars, and journalists interested in studying collective forms of living, relationality, exchange, and obligation. The insights gained from this research project will be used to inform future university courses that I will design and teach related to the anthropology of obligation, solidarity, and kinship. Finally, the outputs produced through this project can be read and used by anyone interested in thinking about how our everyday interactions and obligations are both structured by state power and memories of critical events, and can shape (new) forms of collective living amidst longterm political and socioeconomic violence. The insights produced through this project could provide everyday people (who are neighbors, kin, citizens, non-citizens, activists, etc.) with the vocabulary and perspective that will help them see how their relational obligations impact their daily economic and political life. By doing so, people would be able to make more informed decisions about how to live in community in ways that account for and respond to political and economic violence.
